whether the shares held by the Directors must always be regarded as not held by the public

anchor.surface_text: Two questions, therefore, arise in this appeal. The first is whether the shares held by the Directors must always be regarded as not held by the public. The second is what is the meaning of the provision a company shall be deemed to be a company in which the public are substantially interested, if its shares carrying not less than twenty-five per cent. of the voting power have been allotted unconditionally to, or acquired unconditionally by, and are at the end of the previous year beneficially held by the public.

issues.text: what is the meaning of the provision a company shall be deemed to be a company in which the public are substantially interested, if its shares carrying not less than twenty-five per cent. of the voting power have been allotted unconditionally to, or acquired unconditionally by, and are at the end of the previous year beneficially held by the public

anchor.surface_text: The second is what is the meaning of the provision a company shall be deemed to be a company in which the public are substantially interested, if its shares carrying not less than twenty-five per cent. of the voting power have been allotted unconditionally to, or acquired unconditionally by, and are at the end of the previous year beneficially held by the public. In this connection, we may point out that a ruling of the Privy Council appears to take a different view from that taken by the High Court, in regard to an Uganda Ordinance in pari materia with the proviso and the Explanation.

Public contradistinguished from block acting in unison with >75% voting power
Follows Sardar Baldev Singh: s.23A applies to company controlled by group with >=75% voting power
Analogous to Tatem Steam: mere relation (niece) does not exclude from public absent control
Follows Bjordal (PC): shareholders who are Directors do not cease to be public

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly set aside the judgment and orders of the High Court, and direct the High Court to decide the question originally framed by it,

holdings.text: Directors cannot, by reason of being Directors, be said not to be members of the public.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Mere position as director does not exclude shares from being beneficially held by public; follows Privy Council in Bjordal where director-shareholders were public, and analogy from Tatem Steam on mere relationship.

holdings.text: The word Public is used in contradistinction to one or more persons who act in unison and among whom the voting power constitutes a block. If such a block exists and possesses more than seventy-five per cent. of the voting power, then the company cannot be said to be one in which the public are substantially interested.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation of Explanation to third proviso s.23A; follows own precedent in Sardar Baldev Singh defining control by group with 75%+ voting power.

holdings.text: The essence of the Explanation lies not in the percentage which only shows the limit of the minimum holding by the public, but lies in the words unconditionally and beneficially. These words underline the fact that no person who holds a share or shares not for his own benefit but for the benefit of another and who does not exercise freely his voting power, can be said to belong to that body, which is designated public.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Core textual interpretation emphasizing 'unconditionally' and 'beneficially held' requires free exercise of voting power, not nominee or controlled holdings.

holdings.text: The shares held by Bipinchandra, Harishchandra and Krishnakumar were under the control of their father, Maganlal Parbhudas.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts Tribunal's factual finding on de facto control as supported by evidence; thus these shares not beneficially held by public.

holdings.text: We accordingly set aside the judgment and orders of the High Court, and direct the High Court to decide the question originally framed by it, viz. Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the provisions of s. 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act, XI of 1922, are applicable to the petitioners?
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred by reframing and answering narrow question on sons' shares without determining overall whether public holds >=25%; remands for full application of law to facts.

holdings.text: What the law required was de facto control, a control which is, in fact, exercised.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the tentative opinion that both the tests stated by the Accountant Member and the Judicial Member were incorrect, and held that what the law required was de facto control, a control which is, in fact, exercised, and that no finding appeared to have been given on that point by the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts de facto control test for determining beneficial holding; mere formal tests (interest in managing agency or nominee status) insufficient without actual control over voting.

precedents.citation: Sardar Baldev Singh v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi and Ajmer 1

anchor.surface_text: Sardar Baldev Singh v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi and Ajmer 1 , this Court took the following view The section thus applies to a companypany in which at least 75 per cent. of the voting power lies in the hands of persons other than the public, which can only mean, a group of persons allied together in the same interest.

precedents.case_name: Sardar Baldev Singh v Commissioner of Income-tax Delhi and Ajmer
precedents.cited_proposition: The section applies to a company in which at least 75 per cent. of the voting power lies in the hands of persons other than the public, meaning a group of persons allied together in the same interest; the company is controlled by a group.
precedents.cited_holding: The section thus applies to a company in which at least 75 per cent. of the voting power lies in the hands of persons other than the public, which can only mean, a group of persons allied together in the same interest.

precedents.citation: Tatem Steam Navigation Co., Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 2

anchor.surface_text: Tatem Steam Navigation Co., Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 2 illustrates the first proposition. There, the assessing Commissioners had made directions under s. 21 of the Finance Act, 1922, against which the Company appealed on the ground that it was a Company in which the public were substantially interested

precedents.case_name: Tatem Steam Navigation Co Ltd v Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: Mere relationship, such as niece of a major shareholder, does not make the holder cease to be a member of the public.
precedents.cited_holding: merely because she was a niece of Lord Glanely did not make her cease to be a member of the public.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. H. Bjordal 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. H. Bjordal 1 , the Judicial Committee dealt with s. 21 1 of the Income Tax Ordinance No. 8 of 1940 Uganda , as amended by s. 5 of the Income Tax Amendment Ordinance, 1943. That provision of law is completely in pari materia with s. 23A.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v H Bjordal
precedents.cited_proposition: Shareholders who are members of the public do not cease to be so because they become directors.
precedents.cited_holding: shareholders in a company who are members of the public do not cease to be so, because they become Directors.

precedents.cited_proposition: Reference to the English statute considered in Tatem's case regarding the meaning of public.

precedents.citation: Jubliee Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 3

anchor.surface_text: Jubliee Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 3 , Chagla, C. J., and S. T. Desai, J., speaking of the judgment under appeal and taking into consideration the Privy Council case, observed It may be that our view is erroneous and it may be-and very probably it is-that the view taken by the Privy Council is the right one.

precedents.case_name: Jubilee Mills Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: The Bombay High Court observed that their view might be erroneous and the Privy Council view (Bjordal) likely correct.
precedents.cited_holding: It may be that our view is erroneous and it may be-and very probably it is-that the view taken by the Privy Council is the right one.

The High Court came to the tentative opinion that both the tests stated by the Accountant Member and the Judicial Member were incorrect, and held that what the law required was de facto control, a control which is, in fact, exercised, and that no finding appeared to have been given on that point by the Tribunal.
